title: Angie_Stone
summary: This article reports on the death of Angie Stone, an American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer who died in a van crash on March 1, 2025. The article covers her career highlights from her beginnings with hip-hop trio The Sequence in the late 1970s through her successful solo career, during which she received three Grammy Award nominations and achieved her first number-one album on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart.
extract: Angela Laverne Stone was an American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer. She rose to fame in the late 1970s as a member of the hip hop trio the Sequence. In the early 1990s, she became a member of the R&B trio Vertical Hold. Stone then signed with Arista Records to release her debut solo album Black Diamond (1999), which received gold certification by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) and spawned the single "No More Rain ".

title: Elimination_Chamber:_Toronto
summary: This article details WWE's upcoming "Elimination Chamber: Toronto" event scheduled for March 1, 2025, at Rogers Centre. The pay-per-view will feature two elimination chamber matches with John Cena winning the men's match to earn a championship opportunity at WrestleMania 41, while also marking Cena's final Chamber appearance before his retirement and including his first heel turn since 2003.
extract: Elimination Chamber: Toronto was a 2025 professional wrestling event produced by the American company WWE. It was the 15th Elimination Chamber event and took place on Saturday, March 1, 2025, at Rogers Centre in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. The event aired via pay-per-view (PPV) and livestreaming and featured wrestlers from the promotion's brand divisions Raw, SmackDown and also Roxanne Perez from NXT. The event is based around the Elimination Chamber match, a type of multi-person elimination-based Steel Cage match in which championships or future opportunities at championships are at stake.
text:
{{short description|2025 WWE pay-per-view and livestreaming event}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{use mdy dates|date=November 2024}} {{Infobox wrestling event |name = Elimination Chamber: Toronto |image = Elimination Chamber - Toronto poster.jpg |caption = Promotional poster featuring [[John Cena]] |tagline = |promotion = [[WWE]] |brand = [[Raw (WWE brand)|Raw]]
[[SmackDown (WWE brand)|SmackDown]]
[[WWE NXT|NXT]] |date = March 1, 2025 |attendance = 38,493{{cite web|url=https://www.pwtorch.com/site/2025/03/01/wwe-elimination-chamber-results-3-1-kellers-report-on-mens-and-womens-chamber-matches-sami-zayn-vs-kevin-owens-cody-rhodes-answering-rocks-offer-more/|title=WWE Elimination Chambe results (3/1): Keller's report on Men's and Women's Chamber matches, Sami Zayn vs. Kevin Owens, Cody Rhodes answering Rock's offer, more|date=March 1, 2025|last=Keller|first=Wade|work=[[PWTorch]]|access-date=March 1, 2025}} |venue = [[Rogers Centre]] |city = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada |wwenlast = [[NXT Vengeance Day (2025)|Vengeance Day]] |wwennext = [[NXT Stand & Deliver (2025)|Stand & Deliver]] |event = [[WWE Elimination Chamber|Elimination Chamber]] |lastevent2 = [[Elimination Chamber: Perth|Perth]] |nextevent2 = |event2 = [[WWE in Canada]] |lastevent3 = [[Survivor Series: WarGames (2024)]] |nextevent3 = }} '''Elimination Chamber: Toronto''' (known as '''No Escape: Toronto''' in Germany) was a 2025 [[professional wrestling]] [[List of WWE pay-per-view and livestreaming supercards|event]] produced by the American company [[WWE]]. It was the 15th [[WWE Elimination Chamber|Elimination Chamber]] event and took place on Saturday, March 1, 2025, at [[Rogers Centre]] in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada. The event aired via [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) and [[livestreaming]] and featured wrestlers from the promotion's [[WWE brand extension|brand divisions]] [[Raw (WWE brand)|Raw]], [[SmackDown (WWE brand)|SmackDown]] and also [[Roxanne Perez]] from [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]]. The event is based around the [[Elimination Chamber]] match, a type of multi-person elimination-based [[Steel Cage match]] in which championships or future opportunities at championships are at stake. The event comprised four matches, including two Elimination Chamber matches, one each for the men and women. The main event was the men's eponymous match, which was won by [[John Cena]], earning a match for SmackDown's [[Undisputed WWE Championship]] at [[WrestleMania 41]], while the women's match, which was the opening bout, was won by SmackDown's [[Bianca Belair]], earning a match for Raw's [[Women's World Championship (WWE)|Women's World Championship]] at WrestleMania. In another prominent match, Canada native [[Kevin Owens]] defeated fellow Canadian [[Sami Zayn]] in an [[unsanctioned match]]. The event also saw the returns of [[Randy Orton]] and [[Jade Cargill]]. The event was also notable for Cena's final Elimination Chamber appearance due to his retirement from professional wrestling at the end of 2025, as well as his [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel turn]], as Cena had portrayed a [[Face (professional wrestling)|babyface]] since 2003. This was the first Elimination Chamber event in Toronto and the first WWE event to be held at Rogers Centre since [[WrestleMania X8]] in 2002 when it was still known as the SkyDome. It was also the second Elimination Chamber event in Canada after the [[Elimination Chamber (2023)|2023 edition]] and the fourth consecutive Elimination Chamber to be held outside of the United States. This was also the first PPV to not feature a championship defense since [[Survivor Series (2021)|Survivor Series in 2021]]. ==Production== [[File:Toronto - ON - Rogers Centre2.jpg|thumb|upright|250px|The 2025 [[WWE Elimination Chamber|Elimination Chamber]] was held at Rogers Centre in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, which was WWE's first event in the stadium since [[WrestleMania X8]] in 2002.]] ===Background=== [[WWE Elimination Chamber|Elimination Chamber]] is a [[professional wrestling]] [[List of WWE pay-per-view and livestreaming supercards|event]] first produced by the American promotion WWE in 2010. It has been held every year since, except in 2016, generally in February. The [[Gimmick (professional wrestling)|concept]] of the event is that one or two [[Card (sports)#Main event|main event matches]] are contested inside the [[Elimination Chamber]], which is a type of multi-person elimination-based [[Steel Cage match]] in which championships or future opportunities at championships are at stake.{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/eliminationchamber/2010/exclusives/chamberrules|title=Elimination Chamber Match rules|access-date=February 2, 2010|work=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208084141/https://www.wwe.com/shows/eliminationchamber/history/2010/exclusives/chamberr

The event gained significant attention due to John Cena's shocking heel turn when he attacked Cody Rhodes, as well as Canadian fans booing the US national anthem which prompted commentator Pat McAfee to criticize Canada.

title: Shivon_Zilis
summary: This article is about Shivon Zilis, a Canadian technology executive and venture capitalist born in 1986. It outlines her career trajectory from IBM to leadership roles at companies like Tesla and Neuralink, while also noting her connection to Elon Musk, with whom she has children.
extract: Shivon Alice Zilis is a Canadian technology executive and venture capitalist.

'''Shivon Alice Zilis''' (born February 8, 1986) is a Canadian technology executive and [[venture capitalist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1404242/who-is-shivon-zilis-meet-the-mother-of-3-of-elon-musks-12-children|title=Who Is Shivon Zilis? Meet the Mother of 3 of Elon Musk's 12 Children|work=E! News|last=Finn|first=Natalie|date=June 24, 2024}}</ref>

== Early life and education ==
Shivon Alice Zilis was born in [[Markham, Ontario]], Canada to a [[Punjabis|Punjabi]] [[India]]n mother and a Caucasian father.<ref name=OZY>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/05/29/ozy-shivon-zilis-nerd-athlete-investor/28143597/|title=Shivon Zilis, nerd-athlete investor|work=USA Today|via=OZY|last=Sathian|first=Sanjena|date=May 29, 2015}}</ref> Zilis graduated from Markham's [[Unionville High School (Ontario)|Unionville High School]].<ref name=finpost /> She attended [[Yale University]], graduating in 2008 with degrees in [[economics]] and [[philosophy]]. As a goaltender on Yale's [[ice hockey]] team, she became the school's all-time leader in goals-against average.<ref name=york>{{cite web|url=https://www.yorkregion.com/community-story/1470159-yale-goalie-earns-honour-for-academic-skills/|title=Yale goalie earns honour for academic skills|work=YorkRegion.com|date=March 19, 2008}}</ref>

== Career ==
After graduating from Yale, Zilis started her career at [[IBM]] in [[New York (state)|New York]], working in financial technologies in developing countries, especially [[Peru]] and [[Indonesia]].<ref name=finpost>{{cite web|url= https://financialpost.com/news/fp-street/hockey-skills-helped-canadian-stickhandle-on-to-forbes-top-30-young-investors-list?r|title=Hockey skills helped Canadian stickhandle on to Forbes Top 30 young investors list|work=Financial Post|last=Tedesco|first=Theresa|date=February 11, 2015}}</ref> From 2012 to 2018, she was one of the founding investors and partner of [[Bloomberg Beta]], funded by [[Bloomberg L.P.]], utilizing what she calls "machine intelligence".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/company/stories/current-state-machine-intelligence/|title=The Current State of Machine Intelligence|work=Bloomberg|date=December 11, 2014}}</ref>

From 2017 to 2019, Zilis served as a project director for [[Tesla, Inc.]]'s [[Tesla Autopilot|Autopilot]] product and chip design team.<ref name="nyt">{{Cite news |last=Safronova |first=Valeriya |date=2022-07-07 |title=How Many Children Does Elon Musk Have? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/07/style/elon-musk-children.html |access-date=2022-07-08 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

Zilis served as director of operations and special projects at [[Neuralink]]. Zilis met [[Elon Musk]] through her non-profit work at [[OpenAI]], of which she was a board member until 2023.<ref>{{cite web |last=Peterson |first=Becky |date=March 23, 2023 |title=Shivon Zilis, Musk Associate, Leaves OpenAI Board |url=https://www.theinformation.com/articles/shivon-zilis-musk-associate-leaves-openai-board |website=[[The Information (website)|The Information]] |url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Loizos |first=Connie |date=July 6, 2022 |title=Things get messy for Elon Musk with report about new twins he shares with Neuralink exec |url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/07/06/things-get-messy-for-elon-musk-with-report-about-new-twins-he-shares-with-neuralink-exec/ |website=[[TechCrunch]]}}</ref>

Zilis joined the board of defense technology company [[Shield AI]] in September 2023.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Korn |first1=Jennifer |last2=Glader |first2=Paul |date=November 22, 2023 |title=OpenAI: The cast of characters of Silicon Valley's latest, juiciest upheaval |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/11/22/tech/openai-cast-of-characters-altman/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref> She had previously written the company's [[term sheet]] for a seed round in 2016 while she was at Bloomberg Beta.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cai |first=Kenrick |date=July 17, 2020 |title=Shield AI Rejected A Pivot To 'Selfie Drones'—Now Its Drones Are Being Used By The Military Overseas |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kenrickcai/2020/07/16/shield-ai-ryan-brandon-tseng-ai-50-interview/ |work=[[Forbes]]}}</ref>

==Awards and Honors==
In 2015, Zilis was listed on the [[Forbes

title: Khalil_Fong
summary: The article discusses the life and career of Khalil Fong (1983-2025), a Hong Kong-based American singer-songwriter who introduced sophisticated R&B and soul music to the Chinese market. It outlines his multicultural background, early life across multiple cities, musical development, and professional career from his signing with Warner Records in 2005 until his apparent death in February 2025.
extract: Khalil Fong Tai Tung was a Hong Kong–based American singer-songwriter and producer.

'''Khalil Fong Tai Tung''' ({{zh|c=方大同}}; 14 July 1983 – 21 February 2025) was a Hong Kong–based American singer-songwriter and producer. 

Fong was notable for introducing a more sophisticated [[R&B]] and [[Soul music|soul]] sound to the Chinese music market, drawing inspiration from artists like [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Musiq Soulchild]] and [[Earth, Wind & Fire]].

== Early life and education ==
Khalil Fong was born in [[Hawaii]], [[United States]] to an American-Chinese father, a drummer, and Hong Kong mother, Liang Rulan (梁茹嵐), an English language educator.<ref name="www.chinanews.com.cn">{{Cite web |title=方大同自曝从小家教严格 作风老成拒用音乐追女生——中新网 |url=https://www.chinanews.com.cn/yl/2011/06-15/3113178.shtml |access-date=2025-03-01 |website=www.chinanews.com.cn}}</ref> Liang would later be Fong's lyricist under the pen name Rulan (茹嵐).<ref name="www.chinanews.com.cn" />

Fong moved to Shanghai at the age of 5, then Guangzhou for a brief period before moving to Hong Kong when he was 14.<ref>{{Cite web |last=China |first=Billboard Radio |date=2017-12-13 |title=American-Chinese Superstar Khalil Fong Talks New Label, Publishing Children’s Books |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/khalil-fong-publish-children-books-new-label-8070492/ |access-date=2025-03-01 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="South China Morning Post-2016">{{Cite web |date=2016-06-02 |title=Khalil Fong Won't Be Hong Kong's American-Born Chinese Icon |url=https://www.scmp.com/magazines/hk-magazine/article/2037963/khalil-fong-wont-be-hong-kongs-american-born-chinese-icon |access-date=2025-03-01 |website=South China Morning Post |language=en}}</ref><ref name="Sina Corporation-2013">{{cite web |date=2013 |title=个人明星首页:方大同个人简介大事记 |url=https://ent.sina.com.cn/ku/star_detail_index.d.html?id=fyhvyie0195801&type=event |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240707070436/https://ent.sina.com.cn/ku/star_detail_index.d.html?id=fyhvyie0195801&type=event |archive-date=7 July 2024 |access-date=7 July 2024 |publisher=[[Sina Corporation]] |language=zh}}</ref> Due to the family frequently moving to different cities, Fong initially studied in a primary school in Shanghai for five years, before being homeschooled by his parents until high school.<ref name="www.chinanews.com.cn" /><ref name="Sina Corporation-2013" />
== Career ==
=== Early beginnings: Before being a singer ===
When Fong was 12, the family moved to Guangzhou and he would frequently accompany his father to sing at different bars. When he was 14, after moving to Hong Kong, he started writing over 100 tunes for his mother's English language education company, forming part of the company's audio learning resources. He started to learn to play guitar when he was 15, and subsequently sent many demos to different record companies at the age of 17. However due to his relatively young age and changes in the management of the recording company, [[Warner Records]], he was not able to sign a recording contract until he was 22 in 2005.<ref name="Sina Corporation-2013" /> Until then, he would write songs for other singers such as [[Andy Lau]] and [[Jacky Cheung]].<ref name="Sina Corporation-2013" />

In 2005, Fong finally signed a recording contract with Warner Records.<ref name="Sina Corporation-2013" /> He the

'''Elkie Brooks''' (born '''Elaine Bookbinder'''; 25 February 1945) is an English [[Rock music|rock]], [[blues]] and [[jazz]] singer. She was a vocalist with the bands Dada and [[Vinegar Joe (band)|Vinegar Joe]], and later became a solo artist. She gained her biggest success in the late 1970s and 1980s, releasing 13 UK Top 75 singles, and reached the top ten with "[[Pearl's a Singer]]", "[[Sunshine After the Rain]]" (both 1977), "[[Fool (If You Think It's Over)]] (1981), and "[[No More the Fool]]" (1986).<ref>{{cite book |editor-first=David |editor-last=Roberts |title=British Hit Singles and Albums|year=2006|page=79|publisher=Guinness World Records Limited|isbn=978-1904994107}}</ref>  She has been nominated twice for the [[Brit Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.itv.com/thismorning/articles/elkie-brooks-the-british-queen-of-blues |title=Elkie Brooks, the British Queen of Blues |author= |date=April 22, 2021 |publisher=Independent Television |access-date=November 19, 2021}}</ref>

Brooks is a Gold Badge Award of Merit winner from the [[British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors]] (BASCA) (now [[The Ivors Academy]])<ref name="Ivors Academy">{{cite news|title=Ivors Academy|date=13 October 1999 |url=https://ivorsacademy.com/news/gold-badge-awards-1999-recipients/|access-date=22 November 2020 |last1=Alphonse |first1=Tareic }}</ref> and is generally referred to as the "British Queen of Blues".<ref name="Kent">{{cite news|last=Hunt|first=Keith|title=Elkie's star is still shining |url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kentonline/whats_on/review-elkie-brooks-5665/ |access-date=19 November 2013|newspaper=Kent Online|date=6 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Examiner">{{cite web|title=Elkie Brooks cancels Huddersfield concert after losing voice|url=http://www.examiner.co.uk/news/west-yorkshire-news/elkie-brooks-cancels-huddersfield-concert-4952996|work=News report|date=24 May 2012 |publisher=Examiner.com|access-date=19 November 2013}}</ref>

==Life and career==
===Early career and Vinegar Joe===
Brooks was born Elaine Bookbinder in [[Salford]], to a [[British Jews|Jewish]] family.<ref name="allmusic.com"/><ref name="aboutelkie">{{cite web |title=About |url=https://www.elkiebrooks.com/about |website=Elkiebrooks.com |access-date=21 July 2021 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="jewish">{{cite web |title=Elkie Brooks |url=https://www.jewishlivesproject.com/profiles/elkie-brooks |website=Jewishlivesproject.com |access-date=21 July 2021 |language=en |archive-date=21 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210721214221/https://www.jewishlivesproject.com/profiles/elkie-brooks |url-status=dead }}</ref> Her father's grandparents emigrated to Britain from Poland at the start of the 20th century to escape the [[Pogroms in the Russian Empire|pogroms]]. Her older brothers are Raymond Bookbinder and Anthony Bookbinder (Tony Mansfield of [[The Dakotas (band)|The Dakotas]]).

Whilst still a child, Brooks began singing at barmitzvahs and wedding

title: Budapest_Memorandum
summary: The article discusses the Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances, signed on December 5, 1994, which provided security assurances to Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Ukraine upon their accession to the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Treaty. The agreements were signed by Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, and France, with China providing separate weaker assurances.
extract: The Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances comprises four substantially identical political agreements signed at the CSCE conference in Budapest, Hungary, on 5 December 1994, to provide security assurances by its signatories relating to the accession of Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT). The four memoranda were originally signed by four nuclear powers: Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom and France. China gave somewhat weaker individual assurances in separate documents.

title: Charli_XCX
summary: The article is a biographical overview of British singer-songwriter Charli XCX (born Charlotte Emma Aitchison in 1992), detailing her musical career from her beginnings on Myspace to becoming an acclaimed artist with multiple UK number-one albums. It highlights her evolution through various musical styles, notable collaborations, commercial successes including her 2024 album "Brat," and her recent Grammy wins at the 67th annual ceremony.
extract: Charlotte Emma Aitchison, known professionally as Charli XCX, is a British singer and songwriter. She began posting songs on Myspace in 2008 before entering the London rave scene. Signing a recording contract with Asylum Records in 2010, Charli XCX released a series of singles and mixtapes in the early 2010s. In 2012, she was featured on "I Love It" by Swedish duo Icona Pop, with the song becoming her first number-one hit in the UK and receiving global success. Her debut studio album, True Romance (2013), was released to positive reviews but failed to meet commercial expectations.
